FSSA: Efficient 3-Round Secure Aggregation for Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning

Fucai Luo, Saif Al-Kuwari, Haiyan Wang, and Xingfu Yan This work was supported in part by the Guangxi Natural Science Foundation (No. 2022GXNSFBA035650) and the Major Key Project of PCL (No. PCL2022A03). (Corresponding author: Haiyan Wang and Xingfu Yan)
Fucai Luo is with the College of Computer and Information Engineering, Zhejiang Gongshang University, Hangzhou, China. E-mail: lfucai@126.com.
Saif Al-Kuwari is with the College of Science and Engineering, Hamad Bin Khalifa University, Doha, Qatar. E-mail: smalkuwari@hbku.edu.qa.
Haiyan Wang is with the Department of New Networks, Peng Cheng Laboratory, Shenzhen, China. E-mail: wanghy01@pcl.ac.cn.
Xingfu Yan is with the School of Computer Science, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, China. E-mail: xfyan78@163.com.
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) allows a large number of clients to collaboratively train machine learning (ML) models by sending only their local gradients to a central server for aggregation in each training iteration, without sending their raw training data. Unfortunately, recent attacks on FL demonstrate that local gradients may leak information about local training data. In response to such attacks, Bonawitz et al. (CCS 2017) proposed a secure aggregation protocol that allows a server to compute the sum of clients’ local gradients in a secure manner. However, their secure aggregation protocol requires at least 4 rounds of communication between each client and the server in each training iteration. The number of communication rounds is closely related not only to the total communication cost but also the ML model accuracy, as the number of communication rounds affects client dropouts.

In this paper, we propose FSSA, a 3-round secure aggregation protocol, that is efficient in terms of computation and communication, and resilient to client dropouts. We prove the security of FSSA in honest-but-curious setting and show that the security can be maintained even if an arbitrarily chosen subset of clients drop out at any time. We evaluate the performance of FSSA and show that its computation and communication overhead remains low even on large datasets. Furthermore, we conduct an experimental comparison between FSSA and Bonawitz et al.’s protocol. The comparison results show that, in addition to reducing the number of communication rounds, FSSA achieves a significant improvement in computational efficiency.

Index Terms:
Machine learning, secure aggregation, federated learning, privacy-preserving.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [21, 23] is a promising collaborative machine learning (ML) framework allowing a large number of participating entities to collaboratively train ML models under the orchestration of a server. In particular, FL enables clients to locally train ML models on their data independently and in parallel, which greatly reduces data privacy risks and improves training efficiency and scalability.

In each iteration of FL, the server first selects a subset of clients and sends them a copy of the current global model. Next, each client trains the model locally on their data and computes a local gradient, which is then sent to the server. Finally, the server aggregates these gradients, updates the global model and proceeds to the next training iteration. However, recent results [32, 35, 16] showed that clients’ local gradients may leak information about the corresponding local training data. In addition, these participating clients are usually a large number of mobile or edge devices (e.g., smartphones, personal computers, and IoT devices) with unreliable communication and limited computing power, and therefore can drop out of the protocol. Consequently, the FL system must be resilient to client dropouts. In particular, since the client may drop out of the protocol at any time, the fewer the number of interactions between the server and the client, the lower the number of client dropouts (i.e., client dropout rate). Thus, the number of communication rounds not only affects the total communication cost but also affects the client dropout rate, which in turn affects the model accuracy. Given these concerns, the FL protocol should be optimized to protect the privacy of clients’ local gradients while being highly communication efficient as well as being resilient to client dropouts.

Bonawitz et al. [6] proposed the first secure aggregation protocol to address the privacy of local gradient and client dropouts. At a high level, secure aggregation is a secure multiparty computation (MPC) that allows the server to compute the sum of the clients’ local gradients without having to reveal the clients’ local gradients (even to the server). In fact, secure aggregation inspired several different approaches including: secure multiparty computation (MPC) [7], partially/fully homomorphic encryption [30, 29], functional encryption [1], and double-masking [6, 10]. However, most of these solutions either require more communication rounds [6, 36], do not tolerate client dropouts [39, 2], use heavy cryptographic primitives [12, 33], and/or rely on a trusted third party [20, 44]. In this paper, we focus on the secure aggregation protocols using double-masking.

I-A Contributions

In this paper, we propose FSSA, a 3-round secure aggregation protocol, that is efficient in terms of computation and communication, and resilient to client dropouts. Technically, FSSA is based on the secure aggregation framework of Bonawitz et al. [6] and uses ramp secret sharing [5], key agreement [11], and symmetric encryption to: 1) protect the privacy of the local gradient and, 2) handle client dropouts. Compared with [6], FSSA removes the use of double-masking technique, thereby reducing one round of communication. Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • •

    We exploit an efficient (t,d,n)𝑡𝑑𝑛(t,d,n)-ramp secret sharing, in conjunction with key agreement and symmetric encryption to achieve secure aggregation and tolerance to client dropouts.

  • •

    We provide comprehensive security analysis for FSSA, using a simulation-based proof, which is a standard technique for security analysis of MPC protocols. We also evaluate the performance of FSSA and show that its computation and communication overhead remains low even on large datasets.

  • •

    We give an experimental comparison between FSSA and Bonawitz et al.’s protocol [6]. The comparison results show that, compared with [6], FSSA has a higher computational cost per client, a lower computational cost on the server, and a lower total computational cost. This demonstrates that in addition to reducing the number of communication rounds, FSSA achieves a significant improvement in computational efficiency. However, in terms of overall communication overhead, FSSA does not perform as well as the secure aggregation protocol in [6], which can be seen as a trade-off for getting fewer communication rounds and lower computational overhead.

To our knowledge, the secure aggregation protocols using double-masking technique proposed by [6] are more efficient than other protocols (e.g. those based on homomorphic encryption or MPC), while the few other protocols that require fewer communication rounds either rely on expensive cryptographic primitives (e.g. homomorphic encryption and multi-input functional encryption), or require multiple servers (this usually requires the assumption that there is no collusion between servers; as opposed to the single server required by the mainstream solutions) and do not tolerate client dropouts. These can be seen from Table 1 and related work in Section II. For those based on double-masking technique (e.g. [10, 3, 18, 41]), their core is still the double-masking technique for secure aggregation (see related work in Section II for more details). In conclusion, we believe that a comparison with [6] is sufficient to illustrate the advantages and disadvantages of our FSSA, especially since in this work we are only concerned with reducing the number of communication rounds for secure aggregation protocols while maintaining efficiency.

Remark 1.

As clients in FL join the secure aggregation protocol at different points in time, in any given time interval (for example, in a few minutes, which is much longer than the running time of each client) the server must wait until the last client joins the protocol and then performs an aggregation operation. This means that the execution time of the protocol is mainly determined by: 1) the time of waiting for clients to join the protocol and, 2) the running time of the server (here, we assume that each client has already trained the model locally before joining the protocol). In other words, the running time of the server has a greater impact on the training speed of the model than the running time of each client.

I-B Organization

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. We briefly outline related work in Section II. In Section III, we review some cryptographic primitives we use in our protocol. We then give a technical overview of our protocol in Section IV, followed by a formal protocol description in Section V. In Section VI, we give the correctness and security analysis of our protocol. We evaluate the performance of the proposed protocol and compare it with the previous secure aggregation protocol in Section VII. Finally, Section VIII concludes the paper.

II Related Work

In this section, we survey the existing secure aggregation protocols based on different approaches, which are summarized in Table 1.

Secure Aggregation with Secret Sharing. The first secure aggregation protocol was proposed by Bonawitz et al. [6], who used double-masking technique (with pseudorandom values), Shamir’s secret sharing [34], key agreement [11], and symmetric encryption to protect the privacy of the local gradients and handle client dropouts. However, their secure aggregation protocol requires at least 444 rounds of communication between each client and the server in every training iteration.

Based on the framework of [6], Bell et al. [3] and Choi et al. [10] proposed secure aggregation protocols with polylogarithmic communication and computation overhead. Their protocols achieve better computational and communication efficiency than the secure aggregation protocol of [6] but they are both much more involved and do not reduce the number of communication rounds. The key idea behind [3] and [10] is to replace the complete communication graph of [6] by a sparse random graph and to use secret sharing only for a subset of clients instead of for all clients. However, to ensure the correctness and security of their protocols, the sparse random graph must satisfy a sequence of rigorous conditions (e.g., not too many corrupt neighbors, connectivity after dropouts, not too many neighbors drop out), which make their protocols not suitable for practical applications. In addition, these approaches are generic and therefore apply to our FSSA, but in this work we only focus on how to reduce the number of communication rounds of secure aggregation protocols.

To address efficiency challenge, So et al. [36] recently proposed Turbo-Aggregate, which uses a circular communication topology to reduce the computation and communication overhead of [6]. However, Turbo-Aggregated requires O​(n/log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛O(n/\log n) rounds of communication, where n𝑛n is the number of clients. Beguier et al. [2] proposed SAFER, a secure aggregation protocol between multiple servers with low computation and communication overhead. SAFER achieves low computational and communication costs by combining update compression technique with arithmetic sharing. However, SAFER requires multiple servers and does not tolerate client dropouts.

On the other hand, to guarantee the correctness of the aggregated gradient provided by the server, based on the secure aggregation framework of [6], Xu et al. and Guo et al. proposed VerifyNet [41] and VeriFL [18] respectively. Technically, VerifyNet and VeriFL add verifiability of aggregated gradient on top of [6], so that each client can verify the correctness of the aggregated gradient, thus ensuring that the server computes the sum of clients’ local gradients honestly. However, these verifiable secure aggregation protocols only achieve verifiability (even at the cost of more communication rounds) without improving the efficiency of secure aggregation.

Secure Aggregation with Encryption. Homomorphic Encryption (HE) allows certain operations (e.g., addition) to be performed directly on encrypted data. Such property is exactly what is needed for secure aggregation. A number of proposals [32, 44, 20, 39, 12, 43, 24, 9] have been made to build a secure aggregation protocol for FL using additively HE.

Recently, Fereidooni et al. [14] proposed SAFELearn, a generic design for secure (private) aggregation. SAFELearn can be instantiated with MPC or HE. However, unlike mainstream secure aggregation protocols, SAFELearn requires two servers and assumes no collusion between the two servers. Sav et al. [33] proposed POSEIDON, using a multiparty lattice-based homomorphic encryption scheme [28]. To improve the efficiency of POSEIDON, the authors provided a generic packing approach so that single-instruction-multiple-data (SIMD) operations can be efficiently performed on encrypted data. However, POSEIDON only supports client dropouts when the decentralized bootstrapping is not used. Similarly, Xu et al. [42] proposed Hybridalpha, using a multi-input functional encryption scheme [1] and differential privacy (DP) [13]. With multi-input functional encryption, each client obtains a public key and uses it to encrypt the local gradient, while the server obtains a function key and uses it to compute the average cumulative sum of the clients’ gradients. However, most of these secure aggregation protocols rely on expensive cryptographic primitives and a trusted third party (TTP) that generates public/private key pairs for all clients.

MPC and/or DP. Other works [27, 17, 40, 31, 25] combine MPC techniques and/or DP with ML. However, these protocols usually use some heavy cryptographic primitives and are usually customized for specific ML algorithms, which limits their flexibility and scalability. Therefore, these types of approaches are not suitable for FL.

A well-known secret sharing scheme is Shamir’s secret sharing [34]. However, the coding efficiency of such (t,n)𝑡𝑛(t,n)-secret sharing scheme is low because the size of secret is less than or equal to the size of shares (i.e., only one secret can be recovered per reconstruction). This somewhat limits the utility of the original Shamir’s secret sharing as many practical applications require high efficiency, even more than Shannon perfect security. To address this efficiency problem, ramp secret sharing schemes have been proposed [5, 8, 38, 22], which have a trade-off between efficiency and security. Not surprisingly, ramp secret sharing schemes have been widely used in numerous applications in cryptography, including secure multiparty computation (MPC) [15], error decodable secret sharing [26] and broadcast encryption [37].

III-B Key Agreement

III-C Authenticated Encryption

An authenticated encryption scheme contains polynomial-time algorithms AE=(AE.Setup,AE.Enc,AE.Dec)AEAE.SetupAE.EncAE.Dec\textbf{AE}=(\textbf{AE.Setup},\textbf{AE.Enc},\textbf{AE.Dec}), defined as follows:

  • •

    AE.Setup​(1λ)→s​k→AE.Setupsuperscript1𝜆𝑠𝑘\textnormal{{AE.Setup}}(1^{\lambda})\rightarrow sk: outputs a secret key s​k𝑠𝑘sk.

  • •

    AE.Enc​(s​k,m)→c→AE.Enc𝑠𝑘𝑚𝑐\textnormal{{AE.Enc}}(sk,m)\rightarrow c: outputs a ciphertext c𝑐c, where m𝑚m is a message.

  • •

    AE.Dec(sk,c)→m/⊥\textnormal{{AE.Dec}}(sk,c)\rightarrow m/\bot: outputs the message m𝑚m or ⊥bottom\bot.

The above authenticated encryption scheme satisfies the following requirements:

  1. 1.

    Correctness. For any s​k←AE.Setup​(1λ)←𝑠𝑘AE.Setupsuperscript1𝜆sk\leftarrow\textnormal{{AE.Setup}}(1^{\lambda}) and any message m𝑚m, we have AE.Dec​(s​k,AE.Enc​(s​k,m))=m.AE.Dec𝑠𝑘AE.Enc𝑠𝑘𝑚𝑚\textnormal{{AE.Dec}}(sk,\textnormal{{AE.Enc}}(sk,m))=m.

  2. 2.

    Security. In general, we say an authenticated encryption is secure if it satisfies indistinguishability under chosen plaintext attacks (IND-CPA security) and ciphertext integrity. Here, we omit the specific descriptions of the two security definitions, and refer the reader to [4] for details.

IV Technical Overview

Like previous secure aggregation protocols [6, 10, 3], our protocol consists of a single server and n𝑛n clients 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}, where we assume that each client u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U} has its own input vector 𝐱usubscript𝐱𝑢\mathbf{x}_{u}, and the goal of the protocol is to compute 𝐱=∑u∈𝒰𝐱u𝐱subscript𝑢𝒰subscript𝐱𝑢\mathbf{x}=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}}\mathbf{x}_{u} while making sure that the clients learn nothing more than their own input vectors and the server only learns the sum 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}.

IV-A Secure Aggregation with Shamir’s Secret Sharing

Our observation is that 𝐱=∑u∈𝒰𝐱u𝐱subscript𝑢𝒰subscript𝐱𝑢\mathbf{x}=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}}\mathbf{x}_{u} can be computed using SS scheme. We assume that 𝐱u=(𝐱u,1,…,𝐱u,m)subscript𝐱𝑢subscript𝐱𝑢1…subscript𝐱𝑢𝑚\mathbf{x}_{u}=(\mathbf{x}_{u,1},\ldots,\mathbf{x}_{u,m}). For i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], the client u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U} shares each element 𝐱u,isubscript𝐱𝑢𝑖\mathbf{x}_{u,i} with all other clients using SS scheme: {[[𝐱u,i]]v}v∈𝒰∖{u}←SS.Share​(t,𝒰∖{u},𝐱u,i)←subscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑢𝑖𝑣𝑣𝒰𝑢SS.Share𝑡𝒰𝑢subscript𝐱𝑢𝑖\{[\![\mathbf{x}_{u,i}]\!]_{v}\}_{v\in\mathcal{U}\setminus\{u\}}\leftarrow\textbf{SS.Share}(t,\mathcal{U}\setminus\{u\},\mathbf{x}_{u,i}). After obtaining the shares {[[𝐱v,i]]u}v∈𝒰∖{u},i∈[m]subscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑣𝑖𝑢formulae-sequence𝑣𝒰𝑢𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\{[\![\mathbf{x}_{v,i}]\!]_{u}\}_{v\in\mathcal{U}\setminus\{u\},i\in[m]} from other clients, the client u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U} adds up these shares: [[𝐱i]]u=∑v∈𝒰[[𝐱v,i]]usubscriptdelimited-[]delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑖𝑢subscript𝑣𝒰subscriptdelimited-[]delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑣𝑖𝑢[\![\mathbf{x}_{i}]\!]_{u}=\sum_{v\in\mathcal{U}}[\![\mathbf{x}_{v,i}]\!]_{u}, and then sends [[𝐱i]]usubscriptdelimited-[]delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑖𝑢[\![\mathbf{x}_{i}]\!]_{u} to the server. For i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], the server reconstructs 𝐱i←SS.Recon​(t,{[[𝐱i]]u}u∈𝒰)←subscript𝐱𝑖SS.Recon𝑡subscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]delimited-[]subscript𝐱𝑖𝑢𝑢𝒰\mathbf{x}_{i}\leftarrow\textbf{SS.Recon}\big{(}t,\{[\![\mathbf{x}_{i}]\!]_{u}\}_{u\in\mathcal{U}}\big{)} such that 𝐱i=∑u∈𝒰𝐱u,isubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑢𝒰subscript𝐱𝑢𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i}=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}}\mathbf{x}_{u,i} due to the linearity property of the SS scheme. Let 𝐱=(𝐱1,…,𝐱m)𝐱subscript𝐱1…subscript𝐱𝑚\mathbf{x}=(\mathbf{x}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{x}_{m}), we have 𝐱=∑u∈𝒰𝐱u𝐱subscript𝑢𝒰subscript𝐱𝑢\mathbf{x}=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}}\mathbf{x}_{u}.

Although the above approach successfully handles up to n−t𝑛𝑡n-t dropouts, the obvious drawback is that each client needs to share their own input element m𝑚m times and the server needs to reconstruct the shares m𝑚m times, i.e., running SS.Share and SS.Recon algorithms m𝑚m times, respectively. Note that this approach is similar to the generic MPC protocol based on secret sharing.

IV-B Ramp Secret Sharing to Improve Efficiency

To address the above efficiency issue, we exploit an efficient (t,d,n)𝑡𝑑𝑛(t,d,n)-ramp secret sharing RSS (cf. Section III-A) to achieve secure aggregation.

Given the input vector 𝐱usubscript𝐱𝑢\mathbf{x}_{u}, each client u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U} first divides 𝐱usubscript𝐱𝑢\mathbf{x}_{u} into ⌈m/d⌉𝑚𝑑\lceil m/d\rceil vectors, i.e., 𝐱u=(𝐱u1,…,𝐱u⌈m/d⌉)subscript𝐱𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐱1𝑢…subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑚𝑑𝑢\mathbf{x}_{u}=(\mathbf{x}^{1}_{u},\ldots,\mathbf{x}^{\lceil m/d\rceil}_{u}), and then for i∈[⌈m/d⌉]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚𝑑i\in[\lceil m/d\rceil], the client u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U} shares each vector 𝐱uisubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑢\mathbf{x}^{i}_{u} with all other clients using RSS scheme. The rest of the procedure is the same as in Section IV-A. Consequently, each client and the server only need to call RSS.Share and RSS.Recon algorithms ⌈m/d⌉𝑚𝑑\lceil m/d\rceil times, respectively.

The larger the size d𝑑d of the secret, the higher the computation and communication efficiency. However, to achieve Shannon perfect security, we require that at most t−d𝑡𝑑t-d clients can be corrupted. Therefore, there is a tradeoff between the size of the secret d𝑑d, the threshold t𝑡t, and the number of dropouts (≤n−tabsent𝑛𝑡\leq n-t). Additionally, within the acceptable range of security (in many practical applications, Shannon perfect security is too much security), we can keep the parameter d𝑑d as close to t𝑡t as possible to improve efficiency.

V The FSSA Protocol

We construct FSSA, a new secure aggregation protocol consisting of 3 rounds of communication between each client and the server. We assume that each client u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U} has input vector 𝐱usubscript𝐱𝑢\mathbf{x}_{u} that is in ℤBmsubscriptsuperscriptℤ𝑚𝐵\mathbb{Z}^{m}_{B} for integers m𝑚m and B𝐵B, and ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q} for some large prime q𝑞q is the finite field of the RSS scheme. Clients cannot communicate with each other, but can communicate with the server via some secure channel (e.g., using cryptographic protocols such as TLS). In FSSA, clients may drop out of the protocol in any round and the server can compute a correct aggregated vector as long as the number of dropouts is at most n−t𝑛𝑡n-t (i.e., at least t𝑡t clients survive to the last round). To facilitate the use of the RSS scheme, we also assume that each client is assigned a unique index u∈[n]𝑢delimited-[]𝑛u\in[n]. We provide the complete description of FSSA in Figure 1.

VI Correctness and Security Analysis

In this section, we analyze the correctness and security of FSSA.

VI-A Correctness of FSSA

The correctness of FSSA requires that the server should output a correct aggregated vector at the end of the protocol as long as each client and the server run the protocol honestly and at least t𝑡t clients survive to the last round.

Theorem 2 (Correctness).

Given p​p:=(λ,n,t,d,ℤq,ℤBm,KApp)assign𝑝𝑝𝜆𝑛𝑡𝑑subscriptℤ𝑞subscriptsuperscriptℤ𝑚𝐵KApppp:=(\lambda,n,t,d,\mathbb{Z}_{q},\mathbb{Z}^{m}_{B},\textsf{KApp}), where B<q𝐵𝑞B<q. Let R=n​(B−1)+1𝑅𝑛𝐵11R=n(B-1)+1 satisfying R≤q𝑅𝑞R\leq q. For input vectors {𝐱u∈ℤBm}u∈𝒰subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑢subscriptsuperscriptℤ𝑚𝐵𝑢𝒰\{\mathbf{x}_{u}\in\mathbb{Z}^{m}_{B}\}_{u\in\mathcal{U}}, where 𝐱u=(𝐱u1,…,𝐱u⌈m/d⌉)subscript𝐱𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐱1𝑢…subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑚𝑑𝑢\mathbf{x}_{u}=(\mathbf{x}^{1}_{u},\ldots,\mathbf{x}^{\lceil m/d\rceil}_{u}), if |𝒰3|≥tsubscript𝒰3𝑡|\mathcal{U}_{3}|\geq t, then the server can compute and output the aggregated vector 𝐱=(𝐱1,…,𝐱⌈m/d⌉)𝐱superscript𝐱1…superscript𝐱𝑚𝑑\mathbf{x}=(\mathbf{x}^{1},\ldots,\mathbf{x}^{\lceil m/d\rceil}), where 𝐱i=∑u∈𝒰2𝐱uisuperscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑢subscript𝒰2subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑢\mathbf{x}^{i}=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{2}}\mathbf{x}^{i}_{u}.

Proof.

for i∈[⌈m/d⌉]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚𝑑i\in[\lceil m/d\rceil], which completes the proof.

∎

VI-B Threat Model of FSSA

In FSSA, we want to prevent each client’s input vector (i.e., gradient in FL) from being leaked to other clients and the server, while ensuring that the server obtains a correct aggregated vector at the end of the protocol. As with the previous secure aggregation protocols [6, 36], to preserve the privacy of the input vectors, we consider honest-but-curious setting (a.k.a. semi-honest setting), where both the clients and the server follow the protocol honestly, but attempt to infer information about input vectors of the other clients.

Since both the clients and the server are honest-but-curious, we consider two security notions: one about honest-but-curious clients, where any set of less than t−d𝑡𝑑t-d clients collude (excluding the server) with the aim to infer information about input vectors of the other clients; the other is about honest-but-curious server, where the server colludes with any set of less than t−d𝑡𝑑t-d clients with the purpose of inferring information about input vectors of the other clients.

For completeness, we also give the following description for active adversaries. By active adversaries, we mean parties (clients or the server) that deviate from the protocol, sending incorrect and/or arbitrarily chosen messages to honest clients, omitting messages, aborting, and sharing their entire view of the protocol with each other, and also with the server (if the server is also an active adversary). Like [6], we can only show input privacy for honest clients, as it is much harder to additionally guarantee correctness and availability for the protocol when some clients are actively adversarial, and we also require the support of a public key infrastructure that allows clients to register identities, and sign messages using their identity, such that other clients can verify this signature, but cannot impersonate them. We omit the details of how to achieve the privacy against active adversaries because the construction idea and technique used are the same as [6].

VI-C Security of FSSA

As stated in the introduction, secure aggregation is essentially a multi-party computation. Therefore, we use a simulation-based proof which is commonly used in secure MPC protocols to prove that neither the clients nor the server could learn any information about inputs of the other clients.

For honest-but-curious clients, we show that the joint view of any subset of ≤t−dabsent𝑡𝑑\leq t-d clients can be simulated given only the inputs of these clients. This indicates that these honest-but-curious clients learn “nothing more” than their own inputs.

For honest-but-curious server, in addition to the aggregated vector, the server has information about inputs of some honest-but-curious clients (≤t−dabsent𝑡𝑑\leq t-d clients), so we show that the joint view of such collusion can be simulated given only the inputs of these honest-but-curious clients and the sum of inputs of the remaining clients. This indicates that the server and these honest-but-curious clients learn “nothing more” than the sum of inputs of the other clients and their own inputs.

For simplicity, let 𝐱𝒰={𝐱u}u∈𝒰subscript𝐱𝒰subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑢𝑢𝒰\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{U}}=\{\mathbf{x}_{u}\}_{u\in\mathcal{U}} denotes the collection of inputs from the clients in 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}. Given any subset 𝒞⊆𝒰∪{Server}𝒞𝒰Server\mathcal{C}\subseteq\mathcal{U}\cup\{\text{Server}\}, let REAL𝒞𝒰,λ,t,d​(𝐱𝒰,𝒰1,𝒰2,𝒰3)subscriptsuperscriptREAL𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞subscript𝐱𝒰subscript𝒰1subscript𝒰2subscript𝒰3\textnormal{{REAL}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}(\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{U}},\mathcal{U}_{1},\mathcal{U}_{2},\mathcal{U}_{3}) be a random variable representing the joint view of all parties in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}, where the randomness is over the internal randomness of all parties, and the randomness in the setup phase.

Theorem 3 (Security Against Honest-but-Curious Clients).

Under the same parameter selections as Theorem 2, there exists a PPT simulator SIM such that for all clients 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} with inputs 𝐱𝒰subscript𝐱𝒰\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{U}} and |𝒰|≥t𝒰𝑡|\mathcal{U}|\geq t, sets of clients 𝒰1subscript𝒰1\mathcal{U}_{1}, 𝒰2subscript𝒰2\mathcal{U}_{2}, 𝒰3subscript𝒰3\mathcal{U}_{3}, and 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} with inputs 𝐱𝒞subscript𝐱𝒞\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{C}} such that 𝒰3⊆𝒰2⊆𝒰1⊆𝒰subscript𝒰3subscript𝒰2subscript𝒰1𝒰\mathcal{U}_{3}\subseteq\mathcal{U}_{2}\subseteq\mathcal{U}_{1}\subseteq\mathcal{U}, 𝒞⊆𝒰𝒞𝒰\mathcal{C}\subseteq\mathcal{U} and |𝒞|≤t−d𝒞𝑡𝑑|\mathcal{C}|\leq t-d, the output of SIM𝒞𝒰,λ,t,dsubscriptsuperscriptSIM𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞\textnormal{{SIM}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}} is computationally indistinguishable from the output of REAL𝒞𝒰,λ,t,d::subscriptsuperscriptREAL𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞absent\textnormal{{REAL}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}:

SIM𝒞𝒰,λ,t,d​(𝐱𝒞,𝒰1,𝒰2,𝒰3)≈cREAL𝒞𝒰,λ,t,d​(𝐱𝒰,𝒰1,𝒰2,𝒰3).subscript𝑐subscriptsuperscriptSIM𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞subscript𝐱𝒞subscript𝒰1subscript𝒰2subscript𝒰3subscriptsuperscriptREAL𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞subscript𝐱𝒰subscript𝒰1subscript𝒰2subscript𝒰3\textnormal{{SIM}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}(\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{C}},\mathcal{U}_{1},\mathcal{U}_{2},\mathcal{U}_{3})\approx_{c}\textnormal{{REAL}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}(\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{U}},\mathcal{U}_{1},\mathcal{U}_{2},\mathcal{U}_{3}).
Proof.

Since in this case the server is not involved, the joint view of the clients in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} does not depend on the inputs of the clients not in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. We prove this theorem via a series of consecutive hybrids, where the first hybrid is the real execution and the last one is the simulated execution.

∙∙\bullet Hybrid 0.  This is the real execution REAL𝒞𝒰,λ,t,dsubscriptsuperscriptREAL𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞\textnormal{{REAL}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}.

∙∙\bullet Hybrid 1.  We now change how the symmetric keys of the honest clients in 𝒰2∖𝒞subscript𝒰2𝒞\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C} are generated. Specifically, instead of generating the symmetric keys su,vsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑣s_{u,v} by running su,v←KA.Agree​(s​ku,p​kv)←subscript𝑠𝑢𝑣KA.Agree𝑠subscript𝑘𝑢𝑝subscript𝑘𝑣s_{u,v}\leftarrow\textbf{KA.Agree}(sk_{u},pk_{v}) for v∈𝒰2∖𝒞𝑣subscript𝒰2𝒞v\in\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C}, we choose uniformly random values su,v′subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑢𝑣s^{\prime}_{u,v} as the keys. By the security of the KA scheme, we conclude that Hybrid 1 is computationally indistinguishable from Hybrid 0.

∙∙\bullet Hybrid 2.  We now replace all ciphertexts encrypted by the honest clients in 𝒰2∖𝒞subscript𝒰2𝒞\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C} sent to other honest clients with encryptions of 00 instead of shares of their inputs. By IND-CPA security of the AE scheme, we conclude that Hybrid 2 is computationally indistinguishable from Hybrid 1.

∙∙\bullet Hybrid 3. We now replace the shares of inputs of honest clients in 𝒰2∖𝒞subscript𝒰2𝒞\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C} sent to the corrupted clients in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} with shares of 0. The Shannon perfect security of the RSS scheme (due to |𝒞|≤t−d𝒞𝑡𝑑|\mathcal{C}|\leq t-d) ensures that the distribution of any |𝒞|𝒞|\mathcal{C}| shares of any vector is identical to that of |𝒞|𝒞|\mathcal{C}| shares of 0. It follows that Hybrid 3 is identically distributed to Hybrid 2.

We now define a PPT simulator SIM that samples from the distribution described in Hybrid 3. By transitivity of indistinguishability, we conclude that the output of REAL𝒞𝒰,λ,t,dsubscriptsuperscriptREAL𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞\textnormal{{REAL}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}} is computationally indistinguishable from the output of SIM𝒞𝒰,λ,t,dsubscriptsuperscriptSIM𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞\textnormal{{SIM}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}.

∎

Theorem 4 (Security Against Honest-but-Curious Server).

Under the same parameter selections as Theorem 2, there exists a PPT simulator SIM such that for all clients 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} with inputs 𝐱𝒰subscript𝐱𝒰\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{U}}, sets of clients 𝒰1subscript𝒰1\mathcal{U}_{1}, 𝒰2subscript𝒰2\mathcal{U}_{2}, 𝒰3subscript𝒰3\mathcal{U}_{3}, and 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} with inputs 𝐱𝒞subscript𝐱𝒞\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{C}} such that 𝒰3⊆𝒰2⊆𝒰1⊆𝒰subscript𝒰3subscript𝒰2subscript𝒰1𝒰\mathcal{U}_{3}\subseteq\mathcal{U}_{2}\subseteq\mathcal{U}_{1}\subseteq\mathcal{U}, 𝒞⊆𝒰∪{Server}𝒞𝒰Server\mathcal{C}\subseteq\mathcal{U}\cup\{\text{Server}\} and |𝒞∖{Server}|≤t−d𝒞Server𝑡𝑑|\mathcal{C}\setminus\{\text{Server}\}|\leq t-d, the output of SIM𝒞𝒰,λ,t,dsubscriptsuperscriptSIM𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞\textnormal{{SIM}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}} is computationally indistinguishable from the output of REAL𝒞𝒰,λ,t,d::subscriptsuperscriptREAL𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞absent\textnormal{{REAL}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}:

SIM𝒞𝒰,λ,t,d​(𝐱𝒞,𝐲,𝒰1,𝒰2,𝒰3)≈cREAL𝒞𝒰,λ,t,d​(𝐱𝒰,𝒰1,𝒰2,𝒰3),subscript𝑐subscriptsuperscriptSIM𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞subscript𝐱𝒞𝐲subscript𝒰1subscript𝒰2subscript𝒰3subscriptsuperscriptREAL𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞subscript𝐱𝒰subscript𝒰1subscript𝒰2subscript𝒰3\textnormal{{SIM}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}(\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{C}},\mathbf{y},\mathcal{U}_{1},\mathcal{U}_{2},\mathcal{U}_{3})\approx_{c}\textnormal{{REAL}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}(\mathbf{x}_{\mathcal{U}},\mathcal{U}_{1},\mathcal{U}_{2},\mathcal{U}_{3}),

where

𝐲={∑u∈𝒰2∖𝒞𝐱u,if​|𝒰2|≥t,⊥,otherwise.𝐲casessubscript𝑢subscript𝒰2𝒞subscript𝐱𝑢ifsubscript𝒰2𝑡missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionbottomotherwisemissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\mathbf{y}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{lllll}\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C}}\mathbf{x}_{u},&\text{if}~{}|\mathcal{U}_{2}|\geq t,\\ \bot,&\text{otherwise}.\end{array}\right.
Proof.

The proof of this theorem is similar to that of Theorem 3, with the main difference being that the sum of inputs of the clients in 𝒰2∖𝒞subscript𝒰2𝒞\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C} affects the distribution of inputs of the honest clients.

∙∙\bullet Hybrid 0.  This is the real execution REAL𝒞𝒰,λ,t,dsubscriptsuperscriptREAL𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞\textnormal{{REAL}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}.

∙∙\bullet Hybrid 1.  We now change how the symmetric keys of the honest clients in 𝒰2∖𝒞subscript𝒰2𝒞\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C} are generated. Specifically, instead of generating the symmetric keys su,vsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑣s_{u,v} by running su,v←KA.Agree​(s​ku,p​kv)←subscript𝑠𝑢𝑣KA.Agree𝑠subscript𝑘𝑢𝑝subscript𝑘𝑣s_{u,v}\leftarrow\textbf{KA.Agree}(sk_{u},pk_{v}) for v∈𝒰2∖𝒞𝑣subscript𝒰2𝒞v\in\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C}, we choose uniformly random values su,v′subscriptsuperscript𝑠′𝑢𝑣s^{\prime}_{u,v} as the keys. By the security of the KA scheme, we have that Hybrid 1 is computationally indistinguishable from Hybrid 0.

∙∙\bullet Hybrid 2.  We now replace all ciphertexts encrypted by the honest clients in 𝒰2∖𝒞subscript𝒰2𝒞\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C} sent to other honest clients with encryptions of 00 instead of shares of their inputs. By the IND-CPA security of the AE scheme, we conclude that Hybrid 2 is computationally indistinguishable from Hybrid 1.

∙∙\bullet Hybrid 3. In this hybrid, for each honest client u∈𝒰2∖𝒞𝑢subscript𝒰2𝒞u\in\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C} with input 𝐱u=(𝐱u1,…,𝐱u⌈m/d⌉)subscript𝐱𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐱1𝑢…subscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑚𝑑𝑢\mathbf{x}_{u}=(\mathbf{x}^{1}_{u},\ldots,\mathbf{x}^{\lceil m/d\rceil}_{u}), we substitute the shares of 𝐱uisubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑢\mathbf{x}^{i}_{u} sent to the corrupted clients in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} (in Round 1 of FSSA) with shares of 𝐳uisubscriptsuperscript𝐳𝑖𝑢\mathbf{z}^{i}_{u} for i∈[⌈m/d⌉]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚𝑑i\in[\lceil m/d\rceil], which are sampled depending on 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}, as follows:

  1. 1.

    If 𝐲=⊥𝐲bottom\mathbf{y}=\bot, then we let 𝐳ui=𝟎subscriptsuperscript𝐳𝑖𝑢0\mathbf{z}^{i}_{u}=\mathbf{0} for i∈[⌈m/d⌉]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚𝑑i\in[\lceil m/d\rceil]. In this case, 𝐲=⊥𝐲bottom\mathbf{y}=\bot means that |𝒰2|<tsubscript𝒰2𝑡|\mathcal{U}_{2}|<t, and hence |𝒰3|<tsubscript𝒰3𝑡|\mathcal{U}_{3}|<t.

  2. 2.

    Otherwise, we choose uniformly random vectors {𝐳ui}𝒰2∖𝒞,i∈[⌈m/d⌉]subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐳𝑖𝑢subscript𝒰2𝒞𝑖delimited-[]𝑚𝑑\{\mathbf{z}^{i}_{u}\}_{\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C},i\in[\lceil m/d\rceil]} subject to ∑u∈𝒰2∖𝒞𝐳u=𝐲subscript𝑢subscript𝒰2𝒞subscript𝐳𝑢𝐲\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{2}\setminus\mathcal{C}}\mathbf{z}_{u}=\mathbf{y}, where 𝐳u=(𝐳u1,…,𝐳u⌈m/d⌉)subscript𝐳𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐳1𝑢…subscriptsuperscript𝐳𝑚𝑑𝑢\mathbf{z}_{u}=(\mathbf{z}^{1}_{u},\ldots,\mathbf{z}^{\lceil m/d\rceil}_{u}).

In summary, the joint view of the corrupted parties in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} contains only |𝒞|≤t−d𝒞𝑡𝑑|\mathcal{C}|\leq t-d shares. By the Shannon perfect security of the RSS scheme (due to |𝒞|≤t−d𝒞𝑡𝑑|\mathcal{C}|\leq t-d), we have that the distribution of any |𝒞|𝒞|\mathcal{C}| shares of the vector 𝐱uisubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑢\mathbf{x}^{i}_{u} is identical to that of |𝒞|𝒞|\mathcal{C}| shares of the vector 𝐳uisubscriptsuperscript𝐳𝑖𝑢\mathbf{z}^{i}_{u}, thus making Hybrid 3 identically distributed to Hybrid 2.

We now define a PPT simulator SIM that samples from the distribution described in Hybrid 3. By transitivity of indistinguishability, we conclude that the output of REAL𝒞𝒰,λ,t,dsubscriptsuperscriptREAL𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞\textnormal{{REAL}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}} is computationally indistinguishable from the output of SIM𝒞𝒰,λ,t,dsubscriptsuperscriptSIM𝒰𝜆𝑡𝑑𝒞\textnormal{{SIM}}^{\mathcal{U},\lambda,t,d}_{\mathcal{C}}.

∎

Like [6], we can use a secure signature scheme to convert our FSSA protocol that is secure against honest-but-curious adversaries into one that is secure against active adversaries, but this requires an extra round of communication and a trusted third party to generate secret/public keys. In this paper, we are only concerned with security in the honest-but-curious setting.

VII Performance Evaluation

In this section, we evaluate the performance of FSSA protocol. Similar to [6], in our experiments we use the following cryptographic primitives:

  • •

    Shamir’s (t,n)𝑡𝑛(t,n)-secret sharing scheme to construct the RSS scheme; see below.

  • •

    Elliptic-Curve Diffie-Hellman over the NIST P-256 curve with SHA-256 to construct the KA scheme.

  • •

    AES-GCM with 256-bit keys to construct the AE scheme.

In [38], the authors presented the following simple construction of the RSS scheme using Shamir’s (t,n)𝑡𝑛(t,n)-secret sharing scheme: given a secret 𝐬=(s0,s1,…,sd−1)𝐬subscript𝑠0subscript𝑠1…subscript𝑠𝑑1\mathbf{s}=(s_{0},s_{1},\ldots,s_{d-1}), choose t−d𝑡𝑑t-d uniformly random ai∈ℳsubscript𝑎𝑖ℳa_{i}\in\mathcal{M} and set f​(x)=s0+s1​x+⋯+sd−1​xd−1+ad​xd+⋯+at−1​xt−1𝑓𝑥subscript𝑠0subscript𝑠1𝑥⋯subscript𝑠𝑑1superscript𝑥𝑑1subscript𝑎𝑑superscript𝑥𝑑⋯subscript𝑎𝑡1superscript𝑥𝑡1f(x)=s_{0}+s_{1}x+\cdots+s_{d-1}x^{d-1}+a_{d}x^{d}+\cdots+a_{t-1}x^{t-1}. Then, with the polynomial f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x), we can use Shamir’s (t,n)𝑡𝑛(t,n)-secret sharing to generate n𝑛n shares and reconstruct the secret 𝐬𝐬\mathbf{s} from at least t𝑡t shares. In this work, we use the above construction of the (t,d,n)𝑡𝑑𝑛(t,d,n)-ramp secret sharing scheme in the experimental evaluation of our protocol.

We assume that each element of each client’s data vector is an integer that requires at most 16-bit of storage, i.e., B=216𝐵superscript216B=2^{16}; prior work [19] shows that deep networks can be trained using only 161616-bit wide fixed-point number representation to achieve near-lossless accuracy. For B=216𝐵superscript216B=2^{16}, we can set q=225𝑞superscript225q=2^{25} for any n≤500𝑛500n\leq 500 by Theorem 2. This means that we can encrypt the concatenated elements [[𝐱u1]]v​‖⋯‖​[[𝐱u⌈128/25⌋]]vsubscriptdelimited-[]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐱1𝑢𝑣norm⋯subscriptdelimited-[]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐱delimited-⌈⌋12825𝑢𝑣[\![\mathbf{x}^{1}_{u}]\!]_{v}||\cdots||[\![\mathbf{x}^{\lceil 128/25\rfloor}_{u}]\!]_{v} using the AE scheme in Round 1 of FSSA, i.e., Cu→v​⟨i⟩←AE.Enc​(su,v,(u,v,[[𝐱u1]]v​‖⋯‖​[[𝐱u5]]v))←subscript𝐶→𝑢𝑣delimited-⟨⟩𝑖AE.Encsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑣𝑢𝑣subscriptdelimited-[]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐱1𝑢𝑣norm⋯subscriptdelimited-[]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐱5𝑢𝑣C_{u\rightarrow v}\langle i\rangle\leftarrow\textbf{AE.Enc}\big{(}s_{u,v},(u,v,[\![\mathbf{x}^{1}_{u}]\!]_{v}||\cdots||[\![\mathbf{x}^{5}_{u}]\!]_{v})\big{)}.

In addition, note that the computation cost of the RSS scheme consists of 1) generating n𝑛n shares of the secret, which is the same as that of Shamir’s (t,n)𝑡𝑛(t,n)-secret sharing, and 2) reconstructing the secret, which requires O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) computation by precomputing the Lagrange basis polynomials:

Lu​(x)=∏v∈𝒰∖{u}(x−v)(u−v)​(mod​q)subscript𝐿𝑢𝑥subscriptproduct𝑣𝒰𝑢𝑥𝑣𝑢𝑣mod𝑞L_{u}(x)=\prod_{v\in\mathcal{U}\setminus\{u\}}\frac{(x-v)}{(u-v)}~{}(\textnormal{mod}~{}q)

for any client u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U}.

We run single-threaded simulations on a virtual Linux environment based on a workstation with an Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-8250U CPU @1.60GHz and 16.0GB RAM, and implement FSSA in Python. Since our FSSA takes into account dropouts and corruptions, our experimental results will be shown around these two variables. For simplicity, we assume that clients may drop out of the protocol after sending the public keys to the server but before sending the shares of their data vectors to all other clients, i.e., we have |𝒰1|=nsubscript𝒰1𝑛|\mathcal{U}_{1}|=n and |𝒰2|≤nsubscript𝒰2𝑛|\mathcal{U}_{2}|\leq n, and we let ρ𝜌\rho and γ𝛾\gamma denote client dropout rate and client corruption rate, respectively. In addition, in our experiments the threshold parameter t𝑡t will be set to t=n−ρ​n𝑡𝑛𝜌𝑛t=n-\rho n. To achieve Shannon perfect security of the RSS scheme, given the number of clients n𝑛n, the client corruption rate γ𝛾\gamma and the client dropout rate ρ𝜌\rho, we compute the parameter d=n−γ​n−ρ​n𝑑𝑛𝛾𝑛𝜌𝑛d=n-\gamma n-\rho n (recall that Shannon perfect security requires γ​n≤t−d𝛾𝑛𝑡𝑑\gamma n\leq t-d). For example, given n=100𝑛100n=100, ρ=30%𝜌percent30\rho=30\% and γ=30%𝛾percent30\gamma=30\%, we have d=40𝑑40d=40. On the other hand, if we consider (t−d)𝑡𝑑(t-d)-Privacy that is weaker than Shannon perfect security, we can obtain bigger parameter d𝑑d, thus producing better experimental results. This is a tradeoff between efficiency and security. Note that for the fixed n𝑛n and ρ𝜌\rho, the higher γ𝛾\gamma, the smaller d𝑑d.

In the following, we evaluate the computation and communication costs of FSSA under the following 4 cases:

  • •

    Case 1: Different number of clients and client corruption rates with fixed data vector size and client dropout rate.

  • •

    Case 2: Different data vector sizes and client corruption rates with fixed number of clients and client dropout rate.

  • •

    Case 3: Different number of clients and client dropout rates with fixed data vector size and client corruption rate.

  • •

    Case 4: Different data vector sizes and client dropout rates with fixed number of clients and client corruption rate.

In terms of communication cost, we only give the communication cost per client, and omit the communication cost of the server because it is essentially n𝑛n times the communication cost of each client. We now discuss the above cases and provide detailed experiment results. In the following figures, each plotted point represents the average over 5 iterations.

Remark 5.

Note that in Fig. 2, the curves are not stable, as the running times per client are not long enough to avoid being affected by other unrelated processes running during the experiment. While in Fig. 3, the curves are extremely unstable, as the running times of the server are relatively small (millisecond scale) and therefore vulnerable to other unrelated processes running during the experiment.

VII-A Performance Analysis under Case 1

Computation Overhead. Fig. 2 and Fig. 3 depict the running time of each client and the server, respectively. In general, it is sufficient to consider a maximum client dropout rate ρ𝜌\rho of 30%percent3030\%. For the given ρ𝜌\rho of 30%percent3030\%, it is also sufficient to consider a maximum client corruption rate γ𝛾\gamma of 30%percent3030\%, as such γ𝛾\gamma is close to half of the proportion of undropped clients (70%percent7070\%).

As seen in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, for the fixed ρ𝜌\rho and the data vector size, the running time of each client increases (approximately) linearly with n𝑛n and increases significantly with γ𝛾\gamma for different ρ𝜌\rho, while the running time of the server remains almost unchanged with n𝑛n but increases significantly with γ𝛾\gamma for different ρ𝜌\rho. This is because the running time required for secret sharing (i.e., RSS.Share algorithm) is relatively long and is related to the parameter d𝑑d, which is determined by γ𝛾\gamma for the given n𝑛n and ρ𝜌\rho; in comparison, the running time required for the secret reconstruction (i.e., RSS.Recon algorithm) is so short that n𝑛n has little impact on the computation cost of the server.

Communication Overhead. Fig. 4 shows the total amount of data transferred by each client. We can see that, for the fixed ρ𝜌\rho and the data vector size, the communication cost of each client remains almost unchanged with n𝑛n but increases significantly with γ𝛾\gamma.

VII-B Performance Analysis under Case 2

Computation Overhead. Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 depict the running times of each client and the server respectively when n=500𝑛500n=500. As seen in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6, for the fixed ρ𝜌\rho and n𝑛n, the running times of both the client and the server increase (approximately) linearly with the data vector size and increase significantly with γ𝛾\gamma. In addition, Fig. 3 and Fig. 6 show that the data vector size has a greater impact on the computation cost of the server than the number of clients; see the reason described in Case 1. Note that the curves in Fig. 6 are unstable for the same reasons as in 2; see remark 5.

Communication Overhead. Fig. 7 shows the total amount of data transferred by each client. We can see that, for the fixed ρ𝜌\rho and n𝑛n, the communication cost of each client increases linearly with the data vector size and increases significantly with γ𝛾\gamma.

VII-C Performance Analysis under Case 3

Computation Overhead. Fig. 8 depicts the running time of each client for different γ𝛾\gamma. As seen in Fig. 8, for the fixed γ𝛾\gamma and the data vector size, the running time of each client increase (approximately) linearly with n𝑛n. Besides, as γ𝛾\gamma becomes smaller, the influence of ρ𝜌\rho on the client’s computational cost also becomes smaller. We omit the running time plot for the server because we can see from Fig. 3 that the running time of the server remains almost unchanged with n𝑛n and does not change significantly with ρ𝜌\rho for the fixed data vector size and γ𝛾\gamma. Note that the curves in Fig. 8 are unstable for the same reasons as in 2; see remark 5.

Communication Overhead. We omit the data transfer plot for the client because it is not hard to see from Fig. 4 that the communication cost of each client remains almost unchanged with n𝑛n but increases significantly with ρ𝜌\rho for the fixed data vector size and γ𝛾\gamma.

VII-D Performance Analysis under Case 4

Computation Overhead. Fig. 9 and Fig. 10 depict the running times of each client and the server respectively when n=500𝑛500n=500. As seen in Fig. 9 and Fig. 10, for the fixed γ𝛾\gamma and n𝑛n, the running times of both the client and the server increase (approximately) linearly with the data vector size. Besides, as γ𝛾\gamma becomes smaller, the impact of ρ𝜌\rho on the computational costs of both the client and the server also becomes smaller. Note that the curves in Fig. 10 are unstable for the same reasons as in 2; see remark 5.

Communication Overhead. We omit the data transfer plot for the client because it is not hard to see from Fig. 7 that the communication cost of each client increases linearly with the data vector size and increases significantly with ρ𝜌\rho for the fixed n𝑛n and γ𝛾\gamma. Besides, as γ𝛾\gamma becomes smaller, the impact of ρ𝜌\rho on the communication cost of each client also becomes smaller.

Conclusion. Combing the above 4 cases, we conclude that 1) the computation cost of each client increases (approximately) linearly with both the number of clients and the data vector size for the fixed γ𝛾\gamma and ρ𝜌\rho; 2) the computation cost of the server increases (approximately) linearly with the data vector size and remains almost unchanged with n𝑛n for the fixed γ𝛾\gamma and ρ𝜌\rho; 3) γ𝛾\gamma has a greater impact on the computation and communication overhead of each client and the server than ρ𝜌\rho; and 4) the communication cost of each client remains almost unchanged with n𝑛n, increases linearly with the data vector size, and increases significantly with both γ𝛾\gamma and ρ𝜌\rho.

VII-E Comparison with Prior Secure Aggregation [6]

As mentioned earlier, the secure aggregation protocol of [6] requires 4 rounds of communication between each client and the server in the honest-but-curious setting. By contrast, our FSSA protocol only requires 3 rounds of communication between each client and the server in the honest-but-curious setting. This means that our FSSA protocol has a lower dropout rate ρ𝜌\rho (recall that in FL, the more round, the higher the dropout rate) and thus achieves a higher model accuracy than the secure aggregation protocol in [6] when applied to FL.

Recall that the secure aggregation protocol of [6] used a Pseudorandom Generator (PRG) to reduce the communication. However, as stated in [6], the computational cost of PRG is much higher than that of key agreement, secret sharing/reconstruction, and authenticated encryption/decryption. By contrast, FSSA does not require the expensive PRG operations, and its computational cost is largely determined by secret sharing. However, we note that the data vectors shared using secret sharing in FSSA are longer than that in [6].

We compare the computational cost of each client and the server of FSSA with the fixed (ρ=30%,γ=30%)formulae-sequence𝜌percent30𝛾percent30(\rho=30\%,\gamma=30\%) with that of [6] with the fixed ρ=30%𝜌percent30\rho=30\%. Similarly, we compare the communication cost of each client of FSSA with the fixed (ρ=30%,γ=30%)formulae-sequence𝜌percent30𝛾percent30(\rho=30\%,\gamma=30\%) with that of [6] with the fixed ρ=30%𝜌percent30\rho=30\%. As depicted in Fig. 11, compared with [6], FSSA has a higher computational cost per client, a lower computational cost on the server, and a lower total computational cost (i.e., sum of the computation costs of each client and the server). Therefore, we conclude that FSSA is more computationally efficient than [6], especially as the number of clients increases.

With respect to communication overhead, FSSA performs worse than [6], as shown in Fig. 12. However, in the real-world applications of FL, it is not uncommon for each client to transmit large chunks of data (i.e., megabytes) in each iteration of the model training. Therefore, compared with [6], FSSA incurs larger total communication cost, which usually clients can accommodate in most practical applications. Nevertheless, FSSA requires fewer communication rounds, which achieves a lower dropout rate without incurring any extra computational cost.

VIII Conclusion

In this paper, we investigated how to reduce the number of communication rounds in a secure aggregation protocol, and proposed an efficient 3-round secure aggregation protocol named FSSA. FSSA is resilient against client dropouts and its computation and communication overhead is low enough to be used in mobile applications. In addition, compared with Bonawitz et al.’s secure aggregation protocol, FSSA not only requires fewer communication rounds, but also has less total computational overhead. However, FSSA has a larger communication overhead than Bonawitz et al.’s secure aggregation protocol. We leave reducing the communication overhead of FSSA as a future work.
